> (lengthy, philosophical, article-length)

my reply will not be so long...

> Conceptual Underpinnings
> ------------------------
> 
> So if SuiteRunner seems to be more intuitive in this
> respect, it makes me wonder what it is that motivated
> JUnit's current architecture?

the "cook's tour" in the JUnit doc explains how the framework matured.  If you
look at the whole picture, the framework can be quite complicated but if you
start from the beginning and add one feature at a time, things become clearer.

JUnit was designed to not need a runner to execute the tests (and this
influenced the design with the TestResult).  But today everyone uses a runner so
the design of a new framework (SuiteRunner) would most likely be different.

> Test Sequencing
> ---------------
>
> But it's clear that a lot of thought went into JUnit's design.
> So what is it that makes "sequential tests" undesirable?

if every test share the same resources, you can potentially have some very
tricky problems:

   your testA screws up one field of your suite
   testB.... testY run perfectly
   testZ fails

it can be really difficult to discover that testZ was failing because of testA.

> Assertion Syntax
> ----------------
> 
> I'm not very fond of that, actually, because it's not as
>
> But where JUnit provides a bevy of assertion statements:
>   * assertTrue
>   * ...
>   * failNotEquals(Object, Object)
> 
> SuiteRunner chose to implement only a few:
>     verify(x)
>     fail
> 
> In general, I'm in favor of that simplification. I don't
> see any compelling need to specify:
>     assertEquals(x,y)
> 
> rather than
>     verify(x == y)

After speaking with Bill, I think that it depends on the developer.  I
personally don't like when a test fails and don't give me any clue about what
went wrong.  Simple example:  verify(myVector.contains(myObject)) [or
assertTrue(myVector.contains(myObject))] doesn't give you any clue about what's
in the vector.  You find yourself writing some System.out to discover what's in
the vector.

I prefer to have some clues about what's going on so I like to have plenty of
additional assert methods and classes for my tests (see JUnit-addons and you'll
understand).  For example, I just wrote yesterday a ListAssert class to deal
with the problem.

For the famous rainbow example:

  ListAssert.assertContains(rainbow, Color.orange) returns, if it fails 

  "<expect containing <orange> in <blue, yellow, red, green [...]>"

and I can tell you that it saved my day today.

The answer was in fact quite short. :-)
